column2: The industrial revolution led to a transition from Calcutta towards a first economic model of a workplace with a great appetite for the daily needs of the Mediterranean basin employment.
The revolution created large industrial cities such as Manchester, Birmingham and Liverpool, creating new and large work environments.
The revolution created a split between modern work in factories and traditional work in agriculture, which led to the growth of social and economic discord.
New industries developed during this period, such as the cloth industry, steel, paper, and ports.

The revolution contributed to the development of transportation, with the construction of trains, new possibilities for water transportation and the construction of significant roads. The field of public trains and buses also developed.
